data.title: Wonderful German food and stellar service
data.text: Had the goulash and was thrilled with the quality and the quantity of the food served. Try it with the spaetzle, you will not be disappointed. And the only thing better than the food, was the impeccable service. Each customer was treated like the only person in the restaurant. Before you leave, with your belly completely full, take an everything cookie to go, you'll thank me later.

data.title: Pastries
data.text: Stopped in at the bakery and everyone was very friendly. Pastries were fresh and tasty. Looking forward to going back and trying their lunch.

data.title: Oktoberfest!
data.text: We had a wonderful time at Gerda's 2 day Oktoberfest! Even though it just about rained us out the skies cleared and we enjoyed fabulous german sausage, 1/2 chicken grilled, sauerkraut, spagle, dark beer, music from a live band, and lots of polka dancing! We barely resisted what looked to be extremely delicious desserts! Gerda's is quaint and homey with fantastic food!

data.title: Best food in town
data.text: I absolutely adore the food here. The food is amazing and very big portions. The bakery is even better. The breads and desserts are to die for. The owner still has her German accent for goodness sake. We come here every time we are in Omaha.

data.title: German potato salad!!!
data.text: Gerdas restaurant is small restaurant that is known for its consistent quality.  You can go in for lunch and still have a shot at getting a fresh pastry from the morning.  Must get the German potato salad👍

data.title: Guten appetite
data.text: The food was quite good. I really enjoyed everything I had and so did everyone in my party. The prices were fair I thought at around $17 a meal. The service was slow and the decor could use some upkeep. The bathroom needed some fixing up. They had a large gnat problem also.

data.title: German food sounds great
data.text: We were looking for German food and noticed Gerda's was open for lunch. Each day there is different lunch special, for Thursday it was Wiener Schnitzel, German Potato Salad & Red Cabbage, with Soup or Salad. We both had the special, who could not resist this! Oh wow, what a winner!

data.title: Wow what great food
data.text: We was hoping it to be this good. But to be even better is a rare event. Do stop in and have some German beer and some great food. It's been around for ever

data.title: Doesn't look like much, but the food is awesome
data.text:
I drove over to Gerda's about a half-hour before closing time after seeing it rated as a 'Best of Omaha' in one of those guidebooks you find in hotels.  I looked-up the address and saw a picture of a stripmall storefront and wondered if that could be right.  Anyway, I took a gamble and drove over.

There weren't many people there at the time, so I decided to do takeout and I ordered my usual for a first time in a new German restaurant--Wienerschnitizel.  The host asked if I wanted something to drink while waiting and I decided on a draft beer.  There were two regular patrons sitting at the counter in the bakery side of the place.  They said hello and then proceeded with there normal conversations.  What fun, it was like watching an episode of All in the Family, Omaha style.

Thirty minutes later I was back in my room tasting the food.  Wow!  So good and such a great value.  The schnitzel was perfect, red cabbage the same and the side salad was surprisingly good (including beets, potato salad and they even slice the plum tomatoes in half).  Beats the Hoffbrau House in Las Vegas for sure.  

It's also a great value.  I think I paid $26 for a wealth of food.  Compare that to you typical first course steak in Omaha that will run you $30-$60.

data.title: Good food!
data.text:
A friend recommended Gerda's and he was right!   

I had Jagerschnitzel, spaetzle, sauerkraut, a nice German Bach, and a large piece of German chocolate cake.  Everything was very good.  The sauerkraut was VERY good.  

I liked this place and look forward to going back.

data.title: Jaegaer Schnitzel is perfect
data.text: i go every year to Gerda's for my birthday, this past birthday outing was just as good as my first .  I always the house speciality of Jaegar Schnitzel, that comes with beer or glass of wine, and dessert.  I always ask for the dark German sweet wine, and then have Black Forest cake.   The dish arrived popping hot, a touch of grated cheese over the noodles, and the gravy with it's touch of mushrooms was just perfection.  We did make a reservation and ended up there a little early, but the staff still managed to find us a table even though there was quite the large party already there.  My one daughter always gets the Hungarian Goulash and then sneaks bites off of my plate, and she loves Gerda's Hazelnut cake, which is always moist and fresh bakes as well.   We have had the fried chicken and yes Gerda has earned bragging rights there, and we tend to hit the bakery for a loaf of the fresh baked bread (Gerda usually reminds us to put it in the refrigerator because it has no preservatives. )   We love Gerda's , the staff, the food, the other customers.  Christmas is coming and we will be getting our German Christmas treats there as well, different cookies, pastries, all fresh, all made on premise.

data.title: Best Donuts in Town
data.text: Best donuts in Omaha, hands down.  I am unashamed donut connoisseur and can attest that Gerda's donuts are the best in town.

data.title: Authentic and Cozy
data.text: Gerda's is an original, one-and-only, terrific German restaurant.  Nothing fancy, just decorated in a comfortable "homey" style, found everywhere in Germany.  Dining area is small, very intimate, maybe 8-10 tables, like you're one of the family.  And don't forget dessert; it's a long-standing landmark for German pastries.

data.title: Limited Breakfast and Sloppy Service
data.text:
Perhaps our experience was skewed because we had 6 people, in which case, do not plan on going if you have a 'large' party.  They have only a few options for breakfast.   My son ordered a waffle but the waitress wasn't sure the waffle iron was working, so we told her pancakes was a backup.  The scrambled eggs were supposed to come with toast, according to the menu.  No mention was made to the toast...I assumed we'd get white, but would have expected a bakery to offer choices.  
Later, the food arrived sporadically.   The two quiches were brought out.  Five minutes later, the pancakes were brought out.  Another 5 minutes went by before the egg orders started coming out, by which time we had FINALLY told the quiche people to go ahead and eat.  And plates were being brought out mostly one at a time.  Quiche just needs to be warmed...why was it brought out SOOO early compared to the made-to-order food?!  They were 3/4ths done before the rest of us began to eat.   Not one of the egg orders came with toast, and obviously we were not inclined to ask for it at the point.  The food was just OK, definitely not worth the wait (to me), although the quiche orders were apparently good.   I've lived in Omaha five years and thought I'd been missing out, but I have many other places where I've enjoyed breakfast much more.   I think it was my first and last time at Gerda's

data.title: What a GEM!!
data.text: My family placed a take out order and when we arrived, the staff was great and provided great service and answered all of our questions about the bakery. I have not even mentioned the food, which was fabulous!!  If I am ever in Omaha again, I will go back!

data.title: Salt missing
data.text: We ordered dinners.  Four out of five of us felt the meals were somewhat bland and needed salt.  Staff were very friendly, just not impressed with the items we ordered.  Desert was great though!

data.title: Authenic German Food
data.text:
The place is dated. The service is average to good--friendly folks. It isn't the ritz...
However, I come for the food. You cannot get food like this, except perhaps at the Long Branch in Granby Colorado. ( More Austrian food)  From the red cabbage, the breads, the spaetzel, the Saur-Bratten, the Pork dishes, der schnitzels, the sauces, the potatoes, das Bierren, and finally the deserts--that is why I come to Gerda's. Between the Bohemia Cafe and Gerda's, when I come to Omaha,  I stoke my German ancestry, and my love for " Excellent Peasant Food".

data.title: Good food but bad customer service
data.text: My husband and I were visiting Omaha for the weekend and decided to visit Gerdas for some authentic German food. The salad and beer were good but we left before finishing our meal due to bad customer service. Based on ads I expected a cozy Bavarian atmosphere, but this also left something to be desired.

data.title: Good German food
data.text: Gerda combines good home-cooked German dishes, along with fresh breads, rolls and desserts from her bakery. How can you beat that? Each day has specials at lunch. Friday's special is my favorite. Dinner includes German dishes and her pan-fried chicken. German beers are available to complement any selection.

data.title: Authentic Bavarian Food
data.text:
Gerda's is a cozy family restaurant and bakery that specializes in authentic Bavarian food and wonderful baked goods.  The decor really sets the tone as a slice of Bavaria right here in America.

Good Sauerbraten (German pot roast) is nearly impossible to find, but Gerda's does not disappoint.  They served me the best Sauerbraten I have had in 25 years!  The Schweinbraten (pork instead of beef) has a different sauce that better complements pork, and it is also outstanding.

Gerda's signature dish is Jaeger Schnitzel (pork in a burgundy mushroom sauce), and includes a glass of beer or wine and a slice of Black Forest Cherry Torte for dessert.  Everyone in my group who had the Jaeger Schnitzel raved about it.

Gerda's is a fun family restaurant with truly authentic German food that is delicious, well presented, and reasonably priced.  What a great value!
